title: Mandela's Daughter Becomes S.African Ambassador
text:
Zenani Mandela-Dlamini, the daughter of former South African President Nelson Mandela, has been appointed as her country's ambassador to Seoul.

Mandela-Dlamini, who arrived at Seoul early this month, visited the Foreign Ministry here on Thursday for a meeting with officials.

"We've got great bilateral relations, and I'll continue to work to strengthen them," she told reporters. "We've got great trade relations with Korea and I look forward to strengthen them during my tenure."

Zenani (60) was the first child of Nelson and his second wife and political partner Winnie. She was four years old when her father was imprisoned in 1964 for treason over his resistance to the apartheid regime.

He spent the next 27 years in jail, where Zenani was allowed to visit him for the first time when she was 16. On Thursday she declined to comment on her father.

She met Prince Thumbumuzi Dlamini from the landlocked Kingdom of Eswatini, formerly Swaziland, when she studied at Boston University. They married in 1973.

Becoming acting first lady when her father divorced Winnie after he was inaugurated as South African president in 1994, she maintained the role until her father got married for a third time to Graça Machel, the widow of former Mozambican President Samora Machel, in July 1998.

Mandela-Dlamini will officially take up her post after presenting her credentials to President Moon Jae-in.
